topic.title: Couchbase Web Console
topic.shortdesc: The Couchbase Web Console is the main tool for managing the Couchbase environment.

body.p: The newly designed user interface (UI) offers better usability, increased power and flexibility. Youâ€™ll get a new look and feel, improved navigation, and enhancements to various menus such as Query Workbench, Query Monitoring, Dashboard etc. All menus are now available on the left side pane and the corresponding tabs are located on the right side pane.
The Classic UI link, located on the upper right side, takes you back to the older user interface. To switch back to the new UI from the old UI, click the New UI link.
When you start the Couchbase Web Console, the introductory Dashboard page opens with the tab Cluster Overview selected by default.
The Cluster Overview screen contains three sections: Servers, Cluster, and Buckets.

section.title: Servers
section.p: The Servers section indicates overall server information for the cluster:

row.entry: The number of active servers within the current cluster configuration.
The number of servers that have failed over due to an issue that should be investigated.
The number of servers that are down and cannot be contacted.
The number of servers that are currently waiting to be rebalanced after joining a cluster or being reactivated after failover.

section.p: For more details, see Server setup.

section.title: Cluster
section.p: The Cluster section provides information on the RAM and disk usage information for your cluster.
For the RAM information, you are provided with a graphical representation of your RAM situation, including:

row.entry: RAM Overview section provides a graphical representation of your RAM situation.
Total RAM or the total amount of memory configured for all the servers within the cluster.
The amount of RAM allocated to data buckets within your cluster.
The amount of RAM not allocated to data buckets within your cluster.
The amount of memory that is unused (available) for storing data.
The amount of memory across all buckets that is actually in use (that is data is actively being stored).
Disk Overview section provides similar summary information for disk storage space across your cluster.
The total amount of disk storage available across your entire cluster for storing data.
The amount of usable space for storing information on disk. This figure shows the amount of space available on the configured path after non-Couchbase files have been taken into account.
The free space available for storing objects on disk.

The quantity of disk space in use by data other than Couchbase information.For memory, it is comprised of the memory consumed by all other Couchbase Server processes (beam.smp, memcached, etc.), other processes, and that used by the operating system for disk cache.
The amount of disk space being used to store actively information on disk.

body.section:
Buckets
The Buckets section provides the following two graphs:
Buckets Details
Graph Name Description
Operations per second Provides information on the level of activity on the cluster in terms of storing or retrieving objects from the data store.
Disk fetches per second Indicates how frequently Couchbase Server is reaching to disk to retrieve information instead of using the information stored in RAM.
For more details, see Bucket setup.
